The Eddington luminosity represents the maximum luminosity a star can have before radiation pressure overcomes gravitational force. The formula is:

$$L_E = \frac{4\pi G M c}{\kappa}$$

Where:
- **G** = gravitational constant = 6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ m³/(kg·s²)
- **M** = mass of the object = 6.57923 × 10³¹ kg
- **c** = speed of light = 2.998 × 10⁸ m/s
- **κ** = opacity = 0.31778 m²/kg

**Step 1:** Calculate the numerator
$$4\pi G M c = 4 \times 3.14159 \times (6.674 \times 10^{-11}) \times (6.57923 \times 10^{31}) \times (2.998 \times 10^8)$$

$$= 12.566 \times (6.674 \times 10^{-11}) \times (6.57923 \times 10^{31}) \times (2.998 \times 10^8)$$

$$= 12.566 \times 6.674 \times 6.57923 \times 2.998 \times 10^{28}$$

$$L_E = 1.0433 \times 10^{31} \text{ W}$$
